meals.name: Beef Short Rib Potjie with Potatoes, Warm Bread Rolls, and Chakalaka
meals.description: Slow-braised beef short ribs cooked in a potjie over coals with tomatoes, carrots, and potatoes. Serve with warmed bread rolls and chakalaka for a family braai feast.
prep_steps: Prepare a steady braai fire with medium-low coals; keep extra coals to one side.
Rinse and pat dry beef short ribs.
Combine salt, black pepper, paprika, and peri-peri spice blend; rub all over the ribs.
Slice onions; mince garlic.
Cut carrots and potatoes into chunky pieces (about 3–4 cm).
Open diced tomatoes and beef stock.
Chop parsley for garnish.
Set out chakalaka and bread rolls.
cook_steps: Place a potjie or heavy Dutch oven over medium coals and heat olive oil.
Sear beef short ribs on all sides until browned, 8–10 minutes total; work in batches if needed.
Add onions and garlic; cook, stirring, 3–4 minutes until softened.
Stir in diced tomatoes, beef stock, bay leaves, and thyme; bring to a gentle simmer.
Cover with lid. Move the pot to a low, steady heat zone (barely simmering). Cook 2–2.5 hours, turning ribs every 30 minutes and maintaining gentle heat. Add a splash of stock if the pot gets dry.
Add carrots and potatoes; stir to submerge. Cover and cook 40–60 minutes more until ribs are tender and vegetables are soft.
Taste and adjust seasoning with salt and black pepper.
Wrap bread rolls in foil and warm on the edge of the braai for 5–8 minutes.
Serve ribs and vegetables with some cooking sauce. Garnish with parsley. Add chakalaka on the side and warm bread rolls for mopping up.
Optional oven finish (for steady heat): After searing and adding liquids, cover and braise at 160°C in the oven for 2.5–3 hours, adding carrots and potatoes for the last 45–60 minutes.

meals.name: Leg of Lamb Potjie with Tomato, Rosemary and Pap
meals.description: A slow-braised South African lamb potjie with tomatoes, herbs, and medium warmth, finished low and slow and served with maize meal pap. Built for weekend braai time with an oven finish for steady tenderness.
prep_steps: Set up OutdoorGrill for medium heat with steady coals; preheat Oven to 160°C (320°F).
Cut onions into thick wedges.
Peel and chunk carrots into 3–4 cm pieces.
Scrub potatoes and cut into large chunks.
Smash and peel garlic cloves.
Pat dry leg of lamb and season all over with salt, black pepper, and paprika.
Measure beef stock and open diced tomatoes.
Have bay leaves, rosemary, oregano, and chilli flakes ready.
cook_steps: Heat a potjie or heavy Dutch oven over the OutdoorGrill; add a good splash of olive oil.
Brown the leg of lamb on all sides (8–10 minutes) until well colored; remove to a tray.
Add a little more olive oil to the pot; sauté onions and garlic until lightly golden (4–5 minutes).
Stir in carrots and potatoes; cook 3 minutes to coat in the aromatics.
Add diced tomatoes, beef stock, bay leaves, rosemary, oregano, and a pinch of chilli flakes; stir and bring to a simmer.
Return the leg of lamb to the pot (nestle into the vegetables). Top up with a little water if needed to come halfway up the meat. Cover with lid.
Transfer the covered pot to the Oven at 160°C and braise 2.5–3 hours, turning the lamb once halfway, until fork-tender and the sauce is rich. Adjust salt and black pepper to taste.
About 25 minutes before serving, bring a pot of salted water to a boil on the OutdoorGrill or stovetop and whisk in maize meal to make pap, cooking and stirring until thick and smooth.
Rest the potjie 10 minutes off heat. Slice or pull chunks of lamb and serve over pap with the tomato-herb potjie gravy and vegetables.

meals.name: Cape Malay Chicken Potjie with Turmeric Rice
meals.description: A slow-braised chicken thigh potjie with Cape Malay spice, apricots, and chutney, served with fragrant turmeric basmati rice. Built for the braai fire with a steady simmer and rich, layered flavor.
prep_steps: Light a medium braai fire for steady coals; place a potjie or heavy pot over indirect heat.
Rinse 2 cups basmati rice until water runs clear; drain well.
Peel and slice 2 large onions; mince 4 cloves garlic.
Quarter 4 apricots.
Measure spices: 2 tbsp masala spice blend, 1 tsp turmeric powder (split: 1/2 tsp for potjie, 1/2 tsp for rice), 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1 tsp coriander seeds, 2 bay leaves.
Season 1.2 kg chicken thighs with 1 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper.
cook_steps: Heat 2 tbsp sunflower oil in the potjie over the coals until shimmering.
Brown chicken thighs skin-side down 6–8 minutes, turn and brown 3–4 minutes more; remove to a tray.
Add sliced onions; cook 6–8 minutes until soft and lightly browned. Add minced garlic; cook 30 seconds.
Stir in cumin seeds, coriander seeds, masala spice blend, and 1/2 tsp turmeric powder; toast 30–60 seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 can (400 g) diced tomatoes, 1/2 cup chutney, 2 bay leaves, and 2 cups chicken stock; bring to a gentle simmer.

Return chicken to the pot skin-side up; tuck in apricot quarters. Adjust heat for a very gentle bubble, cover, and simmer 60–75 minutes until chicken is tender and sauce thickens. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Taste and season with 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper (or to taste). Keep warm at the side of the fire.

For the rice: In a pot on the stovetop, combine rinsed basmati rice, 3 cups chicken stock, 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce to low, cover, and cook 12–15 minutes until liquid is absorbed. Rest covered 5 minutes, then fluff.
Serve chicken and sauce over turmeric rice. Scatter chopped coriander on top.

meals.name: Apricot-Chutney Glazed Braai Pork Ribs with Tomato-Onion Smoor and Grilled Rolls
meals.description: Low-and-slow oven ribs finished on the braai with a sticky apricot-chutney glaze, served with a grill-cooked tomato-onion smoor and charred bread rolls.
prep_steps: Heat oven to 150°C.
Line a large baking tray with foil.
Peel and finely chop onions.
Roughly chop tomatoes.
Peel and finely chop garlic.
Roughly chop apricot.
Mix rib dry rub: 2 tsp braai spice mix, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp black pepper.
Pat pork ribs dry with paper towel and remove any tough membrane if still attached.
Whisk glaze: 1/2 cup BBQ sauce, 1/3 cup chutney, 2 tbsp apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp brown sugar, 1/2 tsp chilli flakes, 1 tbsp olive oil.
Split bread rolls for grilling later.
cook_steps: Rub ribs all over with the dry rub.
Place ribs meat-side up on the foil-lined tray; cover tightly with another sheet of foil.
Bake at 150°C for 2 hours until tender but not falling apart.
While ribs bake, light the outdoor grill for medium-high, two-zone heat (direct and indirect).
Start the smoor on the grill: set a cast-iron pot over indirect heat, add 2 tbsp olive oil, then onions and a pinch of salt; cook, stirring, 8–10 min until softened.
Add garlic; cook 1 min. Add tomatoes and chopped apricot; season with 1/2 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp black pepper.
Simmer smoor uncovered over gentle grill heat, stirring occasionally, 25–35 min until thick; move pot closer to or away from heat to maintain a steady simmer. Adjust salt and black pepper.
Remove ribs from oven and discard foil. Brush a thin layer of glaze over both sides.
Transfer ribs to the grill, bone-side down over indirect heat. Close lid and cook 10 min.
Brush more glaze; move ribs briefly over direct heat to caramelize, 2–3 min per side, watching for flare-ups. Repeat glazing once more for a sticky finish.
Toast bread rolls cut-side down over direct heat 1–2 min until charred at the edges.
Rest ribs 5 min, then slice between bones. Serve with smoor and grilled rolls. Offer remaining glaze at the table.

meals.name: Venison Potjie with Root Veg and Fire-Warmed Bread Rolls
meals.description: Slow-braised venison potjie with tomatoes, herbs, and root vegetables, cooked over coals and served with warm bread rolls for mopping up the gravy.
prep_steps: Build a medium bed of coals on the OutdoorGrill; you want gentle, steady heat for 2–3 hours.
Preheat Oven to 160°C for later warming of bread rolls (optional if not using grill to warm).
Cut venison into large chunks (about 4–5 cm).
Peel and chop onions into wedges.
Peel and slice garlic.
Scrub carrots and cut into thick chunks.
Peel potatoes and cut into large chunks.
Pick rosemary and thyme leaves.
cook_steps: Set a heavy potjie or cast-iron pot over steady coals and heat sunflower oil until shimmering.
Season venison with salt and black pepper, then brown in batches until well colored; set aside.
Add onions to the pot and cook until softened and lightly browned. Stir in garlic for 30 seconds.
Return venison to the pot. Add crushed tomatoes, beef stock, apple cider vinegar, bay leaves, rosemary, thyme, and chilli flakes. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Cover with lid and cook over low, steady coals for 90 minutes, maintaining a gentle bubble. Rotate the pot occasionally for even heat.
Stir in carrots and potatoes. Re-cover and cook 45–60 minutes more, until venison is tender and vegetables are cooked through.
Taste and adjust with salt and black pepper. If the sauce is thin, simmer uncovered 10–15 minutes to reduce; if too thick, add a splash of beef stock.
Warm bread rolls: either place on the grill over indirect heat for 5–8 minutes, turning, or warm in the Oven for 6–8 minutes until soft inside and lightly crisp outside.
Serve the potjie hot with bread rolls for dipping.

meals.name: Picanha Braai with Chimichurri, Grilled Corn, and Oven Roosterkoek
meals.description: Fat-cap-on picanha cooked over a two-zone braai for a juicy roast, served with bright chimichurri, flame-kissed corn, and oven-baked roosterkoek. An advanced, slow, weekend-style South African-Latin American mashup.
prep_steps: Light the OutdoorGrill for two-zone cooking: one hot direct side and one cooler indirect side.
Pat dry the picanha steak; score the fat cap in a shallow crosshatch.
Mix braai spice mix, chilli flakes, salt, black pepper, and 1 tbsp olive oil into a paste; rub all over the picanha. Rest at room temperature 20–30 minutes.
Shuck corn and remove silk; rub with 1 tbsp olive oil and a pinch of salt.
In a bowl, combine roosterkoek mix and warm milk to form a soft dough; knead 8–10 minutes until smooth.
Lightly oil a bowl, set dough in, cover, and proof in a warm spot until doubled, 45–60 minutes.
Preheat Oven to 200°C (392°F) with a baking tray inside.
Punch down dough, divide into 8 even balls, and place on a parchment sheet for a 10-minute bench rest.
Melt butter for brushing.
cook_steps: Set the picanha fat-side down over indirect heat. Close the lid and cook 30–45 minutes, turning once, until internal temp reaches about 48–50°C (118–122°F).
Move picanha to the hot direct side, sear 2–3 minutes per side to crisp the fat and build color (watch for flare-ups). Rest on a board 10–15 minutes.
While the meat rests, grill the corn over direct heat 8–12 minutes, turning until charred in spots and tender. Brush with a little olive oil if dry and season with salt.
Slide the rested dough balls onto the hot baking tray and bake in the Oven 15–20 minutes until puffed and golden. Brush immediately with melted butter.
Slice the picanha across the grain into thick slices.
Serve sliced picanha with chimichurri spooned over, grilled corn on the side, and warm roosterkoek.
instructions: Light the OutdoorGrill for two-zone cooking: one hot direct side and one cooler indirect side.
